Multiple-occupancy restrooms signs reading “Men” and “Women” were once considered as progressive as same-sex marriage is today.  In Sinclair Lewis’ classic novel Main Street, liberal, progressive-minded Carol Milford moves from St. Paul, Minnesota, to tiny Gopher Prairie, Minnesota. She is shocked to discover the small frontier town has only a single public restroom facility for both men and women. It’s not a problem for women of the town; they simply use their home bathrooms, but Carol notices that farm women who come to town in their horse-draws wagons refuse to use the gender-neutral facility. Rather than share a restroom with men, they trek out onto the prairies until they can find a tree or bush to squat behind. Carol collects contributions from storeowners to construct a public restroom for women only. It is her first major achievement of her campaign to bring enlightenment to Gopher Prairie.

JFC, you may recall that 1 day you used a photo of Orson Welles, but it turned out the actual Avatar was something else pertaining to the 1938 Halloween broadcast of "War of the Worlds".

Well, the cast and crew of that radio play are all gone now. The last one passed away this month, aged 99. He was apparently interviewed quite regularly about the ability of the broadcast to scare people. The NYT obit has some nice lines about how massively non-credible the thing was.

But he had another claim to fame: He was the regular customer of Sardi's who had been going there the longest. The original Sardi used to let him run a tab, because the theater business can be fickle. At one point, the guy had a steady job at the place next door to Sardi's, which lacked a toilet. So their acquaintance was helpful there as well.

I will believe that he was the Sardi's regular who had been going there the longest, but I'm sure the Times was wrong on what year he began going there. (Check NYT Corrections pages; they almost always have to correct simple facts in obits. For example, the NYT wedding announcement for Morley Safer's daughter said she was keeping the name Safer; but in his obituary, NYT used a different surname for her. The Correction blames CBS for the error.)

The guy went to college in Pittsburgh, then came to NYC; but NYT says he'd gone to Sardi's for 82 years.

Anyway, one play staged by Mercury Theater in 1938 was "Too Much Johnson". Can I type that??
But of course!
